Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: An office function with colleagues of all genders is scheduled this afternoon.
Story:
I stare at my closet, my mind spinning from the argument I had with Amir last night. We’ve been fighting all week about money—he says I spend too much, I say he’s too controlling. As his girlfriend, I know I should try to resolve things, maybe call him before the office function and talk it out. But my phone sits silent on the bed, and I can’t bring myself to pick it up yet.

Meanwhile, the office function looms. It’s a big deal—everyone will be there, including my boss. I know I have to dress modestly, as my faith expects, but I also know my colleagues will be in business suits and cocktail dresses. I worry about standing out, about the stares and the questions. I want to fit in, to be seen as part of the team, but I also want to honor my beliefs.

My heart pounds as I try to choose an outfit that feels right, my mind torn between the need to fix things with Amir and the anxiety of facing my colleagues. I feel pulled in two directions, unsure which expectation to meet first.
